section.header: CAE Test 1: Use of English Part 2
section.rubric: For questions 13-27, read the text below and think of the word which best fits each gap. Use only one word in each gap.
section.text:
Film isn’t just about moving images and spoken language – the written word can also have a strong impact on the big screen. In the first silent comedies and dramas, words emblazoned on a black screen helped audiences to understand what they were seeing. Words spelled out what the characters were saying, and connected the different scenes. For example, in between a scene showing our hero rushing to save his beloved and one|another of her being tied to the train tracks, the word ‘Meanwhile’ would invariably appear on the screen.

Although|Though the introduction of sound

made most of this wording redundant, the written word did not disappear from film. Together|Along with the music, the design of the written title and opening credits helped to set the scene and establish the mood of the film.

The 1930s saw the emergence of different genres of film, each associated with its own distinctive form of lettering. Film posters picked up on this design feature,

which became just as important as the artwork in attracting the right kind of audience to the film. If you agree with certain art critics, you’ll regard these posters as worthless kitsch. for many others, however, they represent a high point in graphic art. A simple sheet of paper was turned into an emotional experience equal to the film itself, with the lettering playing a key role.

section.header: CAE Test 1: Use of English Part 3
section.rubric: For questions 28-37, read the text below. Use the word given in capitals at the end of some of the lines to form a word that fits in the gap in the same line.
section.text:
Archaeologists have used aerial photography for many decades to identify patterns of ancient human activity on the ground. Certain features of an area, such as ancient field boundaries or the outline of settlements and fortifications, which can no longer be seen on the ground, become apparent when viewed from above. The use of such photography has enabled archaeologists to produce maps of how the land has been used over the centuries. But these maps have always had gaps where the land is wooded because traditional cameras cannot see through trees.

Happily a solution to this problem has now been found. It’s called Lidar, and it’s a laser-based aerial detection system that can ‘see hrough’ trees, thus revealing archaeological features concealed in the woodland below. Lidar bounces low-energy laser pulses off the ground and measures the time taken for the light to travel back to the instrument. Most of the pulses coming back are from the trees, but some have reached the ground. A computer selects and analyses these and produces an image of the bare earth. Pioneering work with the new technology has led to the discovery of hundreds of previously

unknown ancient features including military, agricultural and industrial features that are invisible to the naked eye.

section.header: CAE Test 1: Use of English Part 5
section.rubric: For questions 43–50, complete the second sentence so that it has a similar meaning to the first sentence, using the word given. Do not change the word given. You must use between three and six words, including the word given.

question.text2:
One of the footballers was too ill to play that afternoon.

PREVENTED

WHILE

I’d rather you did not eat while you are|did not eat|didn't eat while you are in the car.

so confidently.

recent years.
